data.title: Possible internal python unicode issue
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [no - but see below] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [yes ] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [yes ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [yes] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [not sure] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [yes] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?


### Description

Running python scripts with unicode characters through "script" package or "build + build-python" packages results in UnicodeEncodeError, whereas running the same python script in the terminal has no error.

So, the problem can obviously no be reproduced in safe mode. However, since two different packages fail in exactly the same way, I would tend to think that this is somehow inherent to atom itself: the unicode environment for python is somehow perturbed when launched through atom.


### Steps to Reproduce

1 Install "script" package, or "build" and "build-python" packages
2 Create new file and paste the following line: 
with open("test.txt", "w") as file: file.write("é")
3 execute the script (cmd-i with "script" package, or cmd-alt-b with "build" package (on Mac -- on linux it seems to be cmd-alt-b in both cases)


**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

No error + creation of file "test.txt" containing the single letter é


**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

UnicodeEncodeError + empty file "test.txt"

EDIT : the same problem happens with SublimeText. So there is something really strange happening
 when python scripts are executed from a program instead of in a terminal. But I have no clue auto what.

### Versions

Atom 1.12.6
MacOS Sierra
Python 3.5 (anaconda distribution)

data.title: Grapheme clusters are not properly supported
data.body:
**EDIT: The emoji is now rendered properly but does not behave properly.  See https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13360#issuecomment-272671671.**

I'm running Atom 1.12.6 on macOS Sierra 10.12.1. While many single-codepoint emoji like 👻 are properly supported, emojis consisting of multiple codepoints (connected via [zero-width joiners](http://emojipedia.org/zero-width-joiner/)) like 👩‍👩‍👦‍👦 are not.

Pasting the first into Atom:

![screen shot 2016-11-30 at 8 08 31 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1620098/20753399/3f48f3fc-b6d4-11e6-82c2-af4b637237c3.png)

Pasting the second:

![screen shot 2016-11-30 at 8 08 43 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1620098/20753407/451c35dc-b6d4-11e6-9503-e29e7f79bd68.png)

It seems the joiners are removed, and the individual codepoints are inserted as separate characters. You can reproduce this by simply copy-pasting the emojis from this issue, or using the emoji selector (Ctrl + Command + Space) on a Mac.

data.title: Why bundled themes are broken (in their git repo)?
Add initialize() hook to packages
data.body:
This adds a new hook, `initialize()` to packages. This is meant to be called before any interaction with the package. Like `activate()`, it's passed the serialized state from the previous session. Unlike `activate()`, it's called _before_ deserialization, enabling item deserialization that's dependent on serialized package state.

It might be a little weird that a function called "initialize" can be called multiple times…open to bikeshedding the name!

data.title: Problems editing mixed German/Syriac text
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [YES ] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
* [ YES] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
* [NO ] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
* [ NO] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
* [ YES] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
* [ YES] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

### Description

When editing a mixed-language document (German and Syriac, which is an RTL language), the behaviour at the junctions of these languages as well as inside of Syriac text is erratic at best. I noticed four distinct problematic behaviours:

- it takes around three dozen presses of the left or right arrow keys to step into a half-dozen-letter Syriac word, through it, and back out of it again
- it is almost impossible to place the cursor at the intended Syriac letter using the mouse
- once you click into a Syriac word, the cursor disappears
- (this one is minor) Syriac letters don't obey the letter width of fixed-width fonts such as Courier New

Taken together, these issues are unfortunately a deal-breaker for me. I also have to edit documents combining other RTL and LTR languages and it is day-to-day work for me. This is unfortunate, because I really like that Atom always keeps the document left-aligned instead of deciding alignment line-by-line as e.g. gedit does.

I suspect a connection of what I'm experiencing here to what is described in #4682.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. open atom
2. paste below text into the editing area
3. position cursor before the first letter
4. keep right arrow key pressed; notice time it takes the cursor to move through non-Latin parts of the document
5. try other things described above

```
Olafbeṯ I - *Alphabet I* - ܐܳܠܰܦܒܶܬܼ ܐ. In dieser Lektion lernen wir das Alphabet. Haus, *b*ayto, *ܒ݁ܰ*ܝܬܐ.
```

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.5
Electron: 1.3.9
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12+
git 2.10.2
$ cat /etc/debian_version 
stretch/sid
$ uname -a
Linux t430 4.8.0-1-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.8.5-1 (2016-10-28) x86_64 GNU/Linux
```
I also tested the same atom version under Windows 7 Professional.

data.title: Codepage 850 (European DOS) support
data.body:
Many older DOS files in Europe used codepage 850 which is the European equivalent of 437 which sacrifices some block-drawing characters for common accented symbols in France, Spain etc.

A sample file can be found http://cd.textfiles.com/simtel/simtel9703/disk2/UTILS/TRANSLAT/ESPANOL.TRN

None of the existing codepages can reliably translate this and the codepage is already supported by the underlying iconv-lite library we use.

data.title: Key bindings use default keyboard layout rather than the current one
data.body:
### Description

After upgrading from 1.8.0 to 1.12.5, Atom uses the default keyboard layout rather than the current one when resolving key bindings. If this non-standard behaviour is intended, there should be a switch in the settings that disables it.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Change your **default** keyboard layout to a QWERTZ layout (e.g. Czech).
2. Change your **active** keyboard layout to English (QWERTY).
2. Open the Key Binding Resolver.
3. Press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>-<kbd>Z</kbd>.

**Expected behavior:** _core:undo_ is executed.

**Actual behavior:** _core:redo_ is executed.
#

data.title: change the atom.sh script to launch the local build
data.body:
The `atom.sh` script (which gets copied to the `out`directory during the build process) [seems to be looking](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/0122b7726a1e4eace2a9650b94d9e03c2926c944/atom.sh#L66-L82) in common system-wide locations for an installed Atom version before looking for a local binary, which makes it impossible to use the script to run the locally built atom from the `out` directory.

[According to](https://atomio.slack.com/archives/atom/p1479831997006512) @50Wliu, the batch file on Windows is set up differently and always runs the relative Atom binary. It would be nice if the atom.sh script did the same.
